content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Quite suitable for Clash, and it also provides a new kind of problems.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: funny

You should name your tests : A, true ; x, false ...

Also, you don't test Rotate Left and Rotate Right for "big" values of b. In some languages (like C), the result is undefined for values bigger than the register size. This could lead validator7 and validator8 to fail, but test7 and test8 to succeed, if the player maps the number to a uint8_t.

EDIT : no, the validators don't wail because value of b is '5"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'm not completely sure about reverse but it seems doable.

Why provide c at all? The output could just be the result of applying the operation on a and b. Validation seems like unnecessary complexity.

Why give the operations code letters? As whole words, they could be named more intuitively. Even shorthand like "ROT R" or "SL" or such scheme would be better in my opinion.

Goal
* You may delete all the quotation marks in the list of operators.

Output
* Please add "[[isValid]] and [[result]] separated by a space" between "containing" and ":".

* Please delete "the" before "[[c]]".

* Please change "operand" to "operands".

* Please delete the quotation marks around "true" and "false".

* Please change "representation" to "representation in 8 bits".

Constraints
* Please delete "[[result]]" because this section is not about output requirements.

* Please change "representation are on 8 characters, with leading zero (ex" to "representations are shown in 8 bits, with leading zero(s) where necessary (e.g.".

* Please remove the quotation marks around "00001111".

Stub generator
* Please change "op" to "operator" for consistency.

Thanks.

Thank you.
I corrected it based on your recommendations.
However, for the last one, the replacement of "op" by "operator" is not possible (it is a keyword in C#) but a replace it by "operation", I could not think of another other word...

At first, I wanted to write this puzzle for the Reverse mode only, so I didn't want to display inputs that were too easy. This explains why the input includes 'c' and the output includes the result of the operation.

After writing the puzzle, I thought it could also be used in Fastest and Shortest mode due to its simplicity, so I added some context: "You are a teacher for many students..."

I hope this helps you understand why I wrote it this way. If you have any better ideas, I’m open to suggestions.

It’s my first puzzle, and I wanted to create something easy but not too simple in Reverse mode (I enjoy this mode!).

Thank you.

I didn't name them because I didn't know if the name of the test case are shown in Reverse mode or not and I didn't want to show too much information by naming them 'And false', 'And true'...
But as you suggested I renamed them with just the input value of the operator e.g. : 'a true', 'a false', I just didnt think about it when I wrote it, thanks.

For why there is no test for 'big' value of 'b' for the Rotate Left/Right, I did it on purpose to keep the puzzle easier by avoiding the corner case you told me about.
I think this case is not adapted for the Shortest mode or the reverse one, it makes it more complicated to resolve.
FYI, Reverse mode doesn't show any names (of the cases, and of the clash itself i.e. the title). The only place where hints may be deliberately included is the stub generator.

Oh, that makes a lot of sense actually! For reverse mode it's perfect this way. Well, maybe the uppercase/lowercase distinction isn't the best. You could just use L and R. Having both shift and rotate in addition to the other operations is a bit much anyway.

Note that reverse mode only shows the first 4 test cases, so if you could at least get A O X in there it might be more helpful, especially since exclusive-or can be a less familiar function.

Thank you!

I didn't know how many test cases would be displayed in reverse, so I was unsure how to order them. 
I agree with you, I think I tried to do too much with this puzzle and forgot that it's just a game that doesn't need to be too 'heavy'. The shift and rotate operations are a bit excessive, I totaly agree with you is a bit too much for nothing :D ).

I took your advice and fixed the flaws you highlighted:
- I reduced the number of operations to only four (keeping the most error-prone ones).
- I reordered the test cases so that the four operations are the first ones displayed in reverse (two operations with output 'false' and two with 'true').
- I renamed the shift operations to 'L' and 'R' as you suggested.

"reverse mode only shows the first 4 test cases": Unless the setting has been changed recently or I'm misunderstanding that statement, as far as I understand, reverse mode shows *all* the tests and hides all the validators. The number of tests shown is not limited to 4.

Good to know for next time, thank you.
Have you got a link to provide where this information is shown ?
I don't think there's any link which states such information, but you can see this example (it's the first clash shown): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n4fMQsIQOHA
Thanks you.
D'oh, my bad! I do think the changes were overall beneficial tho.
No problem, I agree with you :)

In that case, you may change the variable name to [[op]] or [[operation]] throughout all sections (Goal/Input/Stub generator). The most important point is to be consistent.

Other points:

Output
* Please change " : [[isValid]] [[result]]" to " [[isValid]] [[result]] separated by a space:". Notice the additional words as well as the changed position of the colon.

Constraints
* Please change "ex" to "e.g."

Thanks.

Done.
Thanks.
